clinical_study.brief_title: Vestibular Function After Chemoradiotherapy for Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma
clinical_study.official_title: Vestibular Function After Chemoradiotherapy for Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma

brief_summary.textblock:
Nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC) is usually treated with chemoradiotherapy. While the effects of this treatment on cochlear function is well characterized, its effect on vestibular function is not well studied.
In this study the investigators will study the vestibular function of 50 patients undergoing chemoradiotherapy for NPC both before and after treatment in order to better define its effects. All patients will undergo a validated questionnaire (dizziness handicap index), posturography, audiometry and vestibular-evoked myogenic potentials.

primary_outcome.measure: Subjective dizziness and vestibular dysfunction using the dizziness handicap index
Vestibular saccular function using vestibular-evoked myogenic potentials

arm_group.description: Patients older than 18 who are planned to undergo chemoradiotherapy for nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

intervention.description: Note that this is standard care for NPC and patients are not assigned to different intervention groups. All patients in the study will receive the same treatment (chemoradiotherapy) and will be observed for changes in vestibular function.

study_pop.textblock: Patients with biopsy-proven nasopharyngeal carcinoma who are planned to undergo chemoradiotherapy.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age 18 years or older.
- Biopsy-proven NPC.
- About to undergo chemoradiotherapy with intensity-modulated radiotherapy (IMRT).
Exclusion Criteria:
- Pregnancy.
- Prior vestibular dysfunction.
